Name: Lenca
Dialects: None known. Some considered it Macro-Chibchan.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Lenca
Location: Comayagua, Francisco Morazán, Intibucá, La Paz, Lempira, and Valle departments.
Population: No known L1 speakers. Some semi-speakers (Adelaar 2007). Ethnic population: 100,000.
name: Lenca

Name: Rufiji
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Central, P, Matuumbi (P.12)
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Rufiji
Location: Pwani region: Rufiji district; Lindi region; central coast, south of Ndengereko [ndg], north of Mwera [mwe] language areas.
name: Rufiji

Name: Teke-Nzikou
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Northwest, B, Teke (B.74)
Dialects: Teke-Eboo. A hybrid of the dialects is emerging among young people.
Language Development: Small scale adult literacy program run by local group and SIL.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Teke-Nzikou
Language Use: Some young people, all adults. Also use Lingala [lin].
Location: Plateaux department: Djambala area; Pool department.
Other Comments: Teke-Nzikou and Teke-Eboo [ebo] can be considered dialects of the same language, though there is no group name, apart from Teke. Both dialects use the same literacy materials. A hybrid of the dialects emerging among young people. Traditional religion, Christian.
name: Teke-Nzikou

Name: Lenca
Dialects: None known. Some considered it Macro-Chibchan.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Lenca
Location: Comayagua, Francisco Morazán, Intibucá, La Paz, Lempira, and Valle departments.
Population: No known L1 speakers. Some semi-speakers (Adelaar 2007). Ethnic population: 100,000.
name: Lenca

Name: Putoh
Classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Dayic, Kelabitic
Dialects: Pa Kembaloh, Abai. May be the same as Lun Bawang [lnd].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Putoh
Location: Kalimantan Utara province: Malinau and Nunukan regencies, Bangalan, Longberang, and Mensalong towns in Mentarang river area.
name: Putoh

Name: Kurumba, Kannada
Alternate Names: Canarese, Korambar, Kuramwari, Kuremban, Kuruba, Kuruban, Kurubar, Kurubas Kuruma, Kuruman, Kurumans, Kurumar, Kurumba, Kurumban, Kurumbar, Kurumbas, Kurumvari, Palu Kurumba, Southern Nonstandard Kannada
Language Development: Younger generation over 50% literate, older generation less. Radio.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kurumba, Kannada
Language Use: Home. All ages. Also use Kannada [kan], Muduga [udg], Tamil [tam].
Location: Tamil Nadu state: Coimbatore district, Pollachi; Dindigul district, Sirumalai and Palani; Teni district, Cumbum Valley; Chingalpattu, Dharmapuri, Salem, and Vellore districts; Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh states.
Other Comments: Reportedly 3 groups of Gowda: Okkili, Anuppa, and Kurumba, which may be languages or dialects of 1 language. Sometimes referred to as Alu or Palu Kurumba, but is a different language from Alu Kurumba [xua] in the hills. Kurumba and Kuruman are different Scheduled Tribes. Hindu.
name: Kurumba, Kannada

Name: Mina (India)
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mina
Language Use: Use a mix of Dhundari [dhd], Mewari [mtr], and Mewati [wtm].
Location: Madhya Pradesh state: Guna, Gwalior, Rajgarh, and Shivpuri districts; Vidisha district, Sironj subdistrict; Rajasthan state: Baran, Jhalawar, Kota, and Sawai Madhopur districts; Uttar Pradesh state: Jhansi and Lalitpur districts.
Other Comments: A Scheduled Tribe. Reportedly L1 is Dhundari [dhd] in Rajasthjan and Braj Bhasha [bra] in Madhya Pradesh. Not a Bhil tribe, and there is no connection between Mina and Wagdi, who call themselves Mina Bhil. Hindu.
name: Mina

Name: Ngarla on the Ashburton river south of the Hamersley range
name: NA

Name: Syenara Senoufo
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Gur, Senufo, Senari
Dialects: Sangaar, Kuleele, Loakloho, Tuvunro, Pomporo, Tagbaar.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 2% in Supyire [spp], 11% in Bambara [bam] (2007 M. Coulibaly). Radio.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sénoufo, Syenara
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Recognized language (1982, Decree No. 159 of 19 July, Article 1).
Language Use: All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Bamanankan [bam], Jula [dyu], Supyire Sénoufo [spp].
name: Sénoufo, Syenara

Name: Tawang Monpa
Alternate Names: Brahmi, Cuona Menba, Dwags, Monkit, Northern Monpa, Takpa, Tawan Monba
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, East Bodish
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Monpa, Tawang
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Sherdukpen [sdp].
Other Comments: Monpa (Moinba), ‘man of the lower country’, refers to several ethnically related peoples, which may not be related linguistically. Buddhist.
name: Monpa, Tawang

Name: Ndonde Hamba
Alternate Names: Chindonde, Chindonde Hamba, Ishiwanda, Kidonde, Kimawanda, Kindonde Hamba, Mawanda, Ndomde, Ndonde, Wanda
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Central, P, Yao (P.24)
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ndonde Hamba
Language Use: Shifting to Swahili [swh]. Also use Makhuwa-Meetto [mgh].
Location: Lindi region: Nachingwea district, Kilimarondo division.
Other Comments: Similar to Mwera [mjh]. Extensive borrowing from Ngindo [nnq]. Muslim, Christian, traditional religion.
name: Ndonde Hamba

Name: Wares
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Wares
Location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Maweswares village on Biri river headwaters south side.
Other Comments: 2005 survey data indicates language may not exist or speakers have moved. Maweswres village now inhabited by Mawes [mgk] speakers. Christian, traditional religion.
name: Wares

Name: Yauma
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Central, K, Ciokwe-Luchazi (K.16)
Dialects: None known. Part of the Ngangela Subgroup.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Yauma
Location: Southeast, isolated enclave in Lucazi [lch] language area, Moxico province; Kuando Kubango Province, Kuando river area.
Writing: Latin script [Latn], plans for future development using this script.
name: Yauma

Name: Pisabo
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Pisabo
Location: Loreto region: in Matsés [mcf] language group territory, between Tapíche and Blanco rivers.
name: Pisabo

Name: Wahau Kayan
Classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, North Borneo, North Sarawakan, Kayan-Kenyah, Kayanic, Kayan Proper
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kayan, Wahau
Location: Kalimantan Timur province: Kutai Timur regency, Telen river north tributary.
name: Kayan, Wahau

Name: Shempire Senoufo
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Gur, Senufo, Suppire-Mamara
Dialects: 3 or 4 dialects. Relationship to Supyire Senoufo [spp] in Mali is undetermined.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sénoufo, Shempire
name: Sénoufo, Shempire

Name: Iapama
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Iapama
Location: Pará and Amapá states border region.
name: Iapama

Name: Tremembé
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Tremembé
Population: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 1,510 (1999).
name: Tremembé

Name: Agariya
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Agariya
Location: Chhattisgarh state: Bilaspur district; Madhya Pradesh state: Mandla and Rewa districts, Maikal hills; Uttar Pradesh state: Agra, Mathura, and Mirzapur districts.
Other Comments: A Scheduled Caste in Uttar Pradesh. Chhattisgarhi [hne] L1 of tribe (Singh 1995b). Traditional religion, Hindu.
name: Agariya

Name: Carabayo
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Carabayo
Location: Amazonas department: halfway between San Bernardo and Pure rivers. At least 3 long houses.
Other Comments: “Macusa” or “Macú”, savage, is arbitrarily applied to uncontacted groups.
name: Carabayo

Name: Punan Merap
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Punan Merap
Location: Kalimantan Utara province: Malinau regency on upper Malinau river.
name: Punan Merap

Name: Khua
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Katuic, West Katuic, Bru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Khua
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized ethnic group: Bru Van Kieu.
Location: West central; Quang Binh province, southeast of Giap Tam.
Other Comments: Part of the Bru Vân Kieu official ethnic community (74,506, 2009 census). Distinct from Cua [cua].
Population: 3,000 (Wurm and Hattori 1981). Total users in all countries: 5,000.
name: Khua

Name: Uru-Pa-In
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Uru-Pa-In
name: Uru-Pa-In

Name: Morerebi
Dialects: None known. Reportedly very similar linguistically to Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], and Uru-eu-wau-wau [urz]. A family group that has not lived with the Tenharim for many years, and does not want contact with outside culture.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Morerebi
Location: Amazonas state: Marmelos and Rio Preto; Mato Grosso state.
name: Morerebi

Name: Himarimã
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Himarimã
Language Use: Contact in 2007 with a mixed group may have included Himarimã speakers.
Location: Amazonas state: Tapauá valley, near the Jamamadi and Jarawara.
name: Himarimã

Name: Yauma
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Central, K, Ciokwe-Luchazi (K.16)
Dialects: None known. Part of the Ngangela Subgroup.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Yauma
Location: Southeast, isolated enclave in Lucazi [lch] language area, Moxico province; Kuando Kubango Province, Kuando river area.
Writing: Latin script [Latn], plans for future development using this script.
name: Yauma

Name: Khua
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Katuic, West Katuic, Bru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Khua
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized ethnic group: Bru Van Kieu.
Location: West central; Quang Binh province, southeast of Giap Tam.
Other Comments: Part of the Bru Vân Kieu official ethnic community (74,506, 2009 census). Distinct from Cua [cua].
Population: 3,000 (Wurm and Hattori 1981). Total users in all countries: 5,000.
name: Khua

Name: Bhalay
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Outer Languages, Southern, Unclassified
Dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 90% with Gowlan [goj].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Bhalay
Location: Madhya Pradesh state; Maharashtra state: Amravati district.
Other Comments: Bhalay probably an alternate spelling of Balahi (Balai), a Scheduled Caste found in Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Rajasthan, and Uttar Pradesh. Traditional religion.
name: Bhalay

Name: Salumá
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Salumá
Location: Pará state: upper Anamu, Trombetas river source, along Suriname border.
Other Comments: Different from Enawené-Nawé [unk] in Mato Grosso. Live among the Trio [tri], losing their ethnic identity.
name: Salumá

Name: Kukna
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Outer Languages, Southern, Konkani
Dialects: None known. Dhule District Kukna has 98%–100% intelligibility with Khandesi [khn].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 10%–30%. Some literacy work being done. Radio. NT: 1977–2002.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kukna
Language Use: Also use Khandesi [khn], especially a group of Kukna in Dhule District. Used as L2 by Khandesi [khn].
Location: Gujarat state: Dangs and Valsad districts; Karnataka state: Dakshina Kannada (Kanara) district; Maharashtra state: Dhule, Nasik, and Thane districts, Dadra and Nagar Haveli; Rajasthan state.
Other Comments: May be the same as Dhanki [dhn]. Hindu.
name: Kukna

Name: Bikaru-Bragge
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: Below 5%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Bikaru
Location: East Sepik province: April river headwaters.
name: Bikaru

Name: Foma
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Northwest, C, Soko-Kele (C.56)
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Foma
Location: Tshopo province: Congo river north side, upstream from Basoko.
name: Foma

Name: Mirgan
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Outer Languages, Eastern, Bengali-Assamese
Dialects: Batasuna, Jagdal Pur, Kosagumuda, Kotpad, Nabarang Pur, Umerkote. Dialects have good intelligibility. Not functionally intelligible of Halbi [hlb]. Lexical similarity: 83%–95% among dialects.
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 10% in Odia [ory].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mirgan
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use Desiya [dso], in Odisha. Also use Halbi [hlb], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Hindi [hin], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Odia [ory], in Odisha, but with low proficiency.
Location: Chhattisgarh state: Bastar district; Odisha state: Koraput and Nabarangapur districts.
Other Comments: Declared a General Caste by the government. Divided into 2 groups, the larger Kabirpanthi and the smaller Sakta. Traditional religion, Christian, Hindu.
name: Mirgan

Name: Tareng
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Katuic, East Katuic, Katu-Pacoh
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Tareng
Location: Xekong province: west of Viet Nam border, east of Kayong, north of Chavane and Thia.
Other Comments: Distinct from Talieng [tdf], which is North Bahnaric.
name: Tareng

Name: Ngombe (Central African Republic)
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Adamawa-Ubangi, Ubangi, Gbaya-Manza-Ngbaka, Southwest
Dialects: None known. May be intelligible of Southwest Gbaya [gso], Bofi [bff], Bokoto [bdt], and Bangandu [ngd].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ngombe
Location: Mambéré-Kadéï prefecture: Gamboula subprefecture, Cameroon border.
Other Comments: Different from Ngombe [ngc] in Democratic Republic of the Congo.
name: Ngombe

Name: Gowlan
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Outer Languages, Southern, Unclassified
Dialects: Dialects in Maharashtra and Karnataka reportedly different. May be more similar to Hindi [hin] (Central zone) than to Marathi [mar] (Southern zone).
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Gowlan
Language Use: Home. Mixed attitudes. Positive attitudes toward Gowlan and Hindi [hin]. Only some want their children to learn Marathi [mar]. Also use Hindi [hin], but with low bilingualism in Chikli area.
Location: Madhya Pradesh state: Hoshangabad district; Maharashtra state: Amravati district, and among Korku [kfq] people; some in north Karnataka state.
Other Comments: Surrounded by Korku. Belong to Gowli caste. Traditional religion, Christian.
name: Gowlan

Name: Chamari
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Western Hindi, Unclassified
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Chamari
Location: Madhya Pradesh and Maharastra states; Uttar Pradesh state: Lucknow.
Other Comments: Chamar is a caste name for skin and hide workers. Speakers throughout India (Singh 1995b). Traditional religion.
name: Chamari

Name: Nagarchal
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Nagarchal
Language Use: Shifted to Hindi and Northern Gondi [gno].
Location: Madhya Pradesh state: Balaghat, Chhindwara, Mandla, and Seoni districts.
Other Comments: Nagarchi is a people group living in Seoni, Jabalpur, and Mandla districts of Madhya Pradesh who speak Hindi [hin] (Singh 1998a).
name: Nagarchal

Name: Norra
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Nora
Location: Arunachal Pradesh state: northeast, near Tibet.
name: Nora

Name: Quetzaltepec Mixe
Alternate Names: Central Mixe, Chuxnabán Mixe, Midland Mixe, Mixe Alto del Sur
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mixe, Quetzaltepec
name: Mixe, Quetzaltepec

Name: Kiorr
Alternate Names: Col, Con, Saamtaav, Samtao, Samtao II
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Northern Mon-Khmer, Palaungic, Eastern Palaungic, Angkuic
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kiorr
Location: Luang Namtha and Oudomxai provinces: 6 villages.
name: Kiorr

Name: Inpui Naga
Alternate Names: Kabui, Kabui Naga, Kapwi, Koboi, Kubai
Dialects: None known. Considered by some to be the same language as Puimei Naga [npu]. Lexical similarity: 68% with Puimei Naga [npu].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L2: 70% in English [eng] and in Meitei [mni] (Bengali script) (2000). Literacy high among young people in Meitei and English. Literature. NT: 2011.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Naga, Inpui
Language Use: Home, religion. All ages. Positive attitudes. Most also use Meitei [mni]. Also use English [eng], Rongmei Naga [nbu].
Location: Assam state; Manipur state: Imphal, Senapati, and Tamenglong Imphal districts, 16 villages; Nagaland state: Dimapur, Mahei Namchi, New Zaluke, and Peren.
Other Comments: Kabui recognized as Scheduled Tribe combining Inpui and Rongmei. Christian.
name: Naga, Inpui

Name: Pardhan
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Pardhan
Language Use: Also use Hindi [hin], in Madhya Pradesh. Also use Marathi [mar], in Maharashtra.
Location: Chhattisgarh state: Bilaspur, Raipur, and Surguja districts; Madhya Pradesh state: Balaghat, Betul, Chhindwara, Hoshangabad, Jabalpur, Mandla, and Seoni districts; Maharashtra state: Bhandara, Garhchiroli, Nagpur, Wardha, and Yavatmal districts; Telangana state: possibly in Adilbad district.
name: Pardhan

Name: Katukína
Alternate Names: Catuquina, Katukina do Jutaí, Katukina do Rio Biá, Pidá-Djapá
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Katukína
Other Comments: Different from Panoan Katukína [knt] in Amazonas and Acre.
Population: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 590 (2008 FUNASA).
name: Katukína

Name: Con
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Northern Mon-Khmer, Palaungic, Eastern Palaungic, Lametic
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Con
Location: Bokeo province: Meung district; Luang Namtha province: southwest of Vieng Pou Kha.
name: Con

Name: Narau
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Narau
Other Comments: 2006 survey data indicates language may not exist and could possibly be merged with Kosare [kiq]. Christian, traditional religion.
name: Narau

Name: Mengisa
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Northwest, A, Ewondo-Fang (A.71)
Dialects: High exposure to and 97% intelligibility of Ewondo [ewo]. But Ewondo speakers have only 46% with Mengisa. The Mangisa people speak 2 languages: the Mengisa (Njowi) [mct], spoken in the Lekie division, and Leti [leo], closely related to, and perhaps a dialect of, Tuki [bag]. Eton [eto], the A70 variety reportedly most similar to Mengisa (Njowi) is 90% cognate with Mengisa, but a lower comprehension level (91%) (1990 D. Hatfield and C. Regnier). Lexical similarity: 90%–91% with Eton [eto], 81%–97% with Ewondo [ewo] (Risnes 1989).
Language Development: No literacy program in place. Radio.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mengisa
Language Use: Children losing L1 capability, even in the village. Much intermarriage with Eton [eto], Ewondo [ewo] and certain Mbam languages. Children highly bilingual. Home, with other Mengisa, markets. All ages. Mixed attitudes. Also use Eton [etn], Ewondo [ewo]. Used as L2 by Leti [leo].
Location: Centre region: Lekié division, Sa’a subdivision, Sanaga river bend area between the river and Sa’a.
Other Comments: The Mangisa people speak 2 languages: Mengisa (Njowi) and Leti [leo]. Christian.
name: Mengisa

Name: Anasi
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Anasi
Location: Papua province: Jayapura regency, Mamberamo Hilir sub-district on north coast, lower west bank Mamberamo river.
name: Anasi

Name: Gowli
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Western Hindi, Unclassified
Dialects: Nand, Ranya, Lingaayat, Khamla. Nand subdialects have 93% or higher intelligibility with Khamla dialect. Dialect used in Madhya Pradesh appears more similar to Marathi [mar] (Southern zone) than to Hindi [hin] (Central zone). Lexical similarity: 84%–92% between the Ranya and Nand dialects.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Gowli
Location: Madhya Pradesh state; Maharashtra state: Amravati district.
Other Comments: Speakers belong to Gowli caste. 1 and a half subgroups; Nand Gowli the highest, Musalman (the half tribe) the lowest. Surrounded by Korku [kfq]. Hindu, traditional religion.
name: Gowli

Name: Samre of Siem Reap
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Pearic, Western, Samre
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Samre
Location: Siem Reap province: Siem Reap town area north of Lake Sap.
Population: No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 200 (2000 D. Bradley).
name: Samre

Name: Kayort
Classification: Indo-European, Indo-Iranian, Indo-Aryan, Outer Languages, Eastern, Bengali-Assamese
Dialects: None known. Ostensibly related to Bengali [ben].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kewat
Other Comments: No known published or survey-based attestation for this as a separate language variety.
name: Kewat

Name: Puimei Naga
Dialects: None known. Different from Poumei Naga [pmx] (Breton 1997:217). Not functionally intelligible of any related language (Khasung). Lexical similarity: 68% with Inpui Naga [nkf].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Naga, Puimei
Other Comments: Were assigned as part of Rongmei Naga [nbu]. Christian, traditional religion.
name: Naga, Puimei

Name: Balau
Dialects: May be a dialect of Iban [iba].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Balau
Other Comments: View themselves as a distinct ethnic group.
name: Balau

Name: Kang
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kang
Population: 47,600 (1995 census). Total users in all countries: 81,700.
name: Kang

Name: Bubia
Alternate Names: Bobe, Bobea, Bota, Ewota, Wovea, Wuvia
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Narrow Bantu, Northwest, A, Bubi-Benga (A.31)
Dialects: None known. Closely related to Bube [bvb].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Bubia
Location: South West region: Fako division, Limbé subdivision, Wovea village.
Typology: 10 noun classes; 21 consonant and 7 vowel phonemes; tonal.
name: Bubia

Name: Khlor
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Katuic, East Katuic, Ngeq-Nkriang
Dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Kriang [ngt].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Khlor
Location: Salavan province: Laongam district; Xekong province.
name: Khlor

Name: Buraka
Also spoken in: {u'View other languages of Democratic Republic of the Congo': {}}
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Adamawa-Ubangi, Ubangi, Sere-Ngbaka-Mba, Ngbaka-Mba, Ngbaka, Western, Gbanzili
Dialects: None known. May not be inherently intelligible with Gbanziri [gbg].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Buraka
Location: Basse-Kotto prefecture: Mobaye subprefecture, along Ubangi river.
name: Buraka

Name: Aduge
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Edoid, Northwestern
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Aduge
name: Aduge

Name: Ir
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Eastern Mon-Khmer, Katuic, Central Katuic, Ta’oih
Dialects: None known. Reportedly most similar to Ong [oog].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ir
Location: Salavan province: east of Salavan town.
name: Ir

Name: Warduji
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Warduji
Location: Badakhshan province: Werdoge river area west of Ishkashim.
name: Warduji

Name: Sikiana
Alternate Names: Chikena, Chiquena, Chiquiana, Shikiana, Sikiâna, Sikïiyana, Xikiyana, Xikujana
Dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Salumá [slj].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sikiana
Location: Pará state: between Rio Cafuini and headwaters of the Turuna and Itapi, near the Suriname border.
Population: 33 (1986 SIL). Total users in all countries: 48.
name: Sikiana

Name: Sikiana
Alternate Names: Chikena, Chiquena, Chiquiana, Shikiana, Sikiâna, Sikïiyana, Xikiyana, Xikujana
Dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Salumá [slj].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sikiana
Location: Pará state: between Rio Cafuini and headwaters of the Turuna and Itapi, near the Suriname border.
Population: 33 (1986 SIL). Total users in all countries: 48.
name: Sikiana

Name: Chetco
Classification: Eyak-Athabaskan, Athabaskan, Pacific Coast Athabaskan, Oregon Athabaskan, Tolowa-Chetco
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Chetco
name: Chetco

Name: Kofa
Dialects: None known. Reportedly a separate language from Bura-Pabir [bwr].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kofa
Location: Adamawa state: Song LGA, north of Belul road, north of Yola.
name: Kofa

Name: Lama (Myanmar)
Alternate Names: Lama, Lan-Bi Bai, Nama, Northern Bai
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Bai, Lama
Location: Yunnan province: Diqing Tibetan autonomous prefecture; Nujiang Lisu autonomous prefecture, Lanping Bai Pumi autonomous county, Hexi district, Lajing township; mountain area of Lancang river.
Other Comments: Classification difficult due to heavy borrowing (60%–70%) from Chinese. Northern Bai comprises two separate languages, Panyi [bfc] and Lama. Traditional religion, Buddhist, Daoist.
name: Bai, Lama

Name: Northwestern Tamang
Alternate Names: Kath-Bhotiya, Lama Bhote, Murmi, Rongba, Sain, Tamang Gyoi, Tamang Gyot, Tamang Lengmo, Tamang Tam
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, West Bodish, Gurung-Tamang, Tamang
Dialects: Dhading. All Western Tamang varieties have high mutual intelligibility. Lexical similarity: 94% with Western Trisuli Tamang [tdg], 82%–83% with Western Rasuwa Tamang [tdg], 76%–77% with Eastern Gorkha Tamang [tge], 72%–80% with Eastern Tamang [taj].
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 1%–10%. Literacy rate in L2: 25%–75%. Taught in primary schools. Literature. Newspapers. Periodicals. Radio. Dictionary. Texts. NT: 1990.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Tamang, Northwestern
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized indigenous nationality: Tamang.
Language Use: Home; mixed use: Friends, religion, work, education. All ages. Positive attitudes. Also use Central Tibetan [bod], in religious contexts. Also use Nepali [npi], in official contexts.
Location: Bagmati zone: Nuwakot district, central mountainous strip.
Population: 67,200 (2011 census), increasing. Population for all Tamang varieties: 1,350,000 (2011 census).
Typology: SOV; postpositions; noun head both initial and final; no noun classes or gender; no prefixes, up to 4 suffixes; clause constituents indicated by case-marking; ergativity; genitives after noun head; relatives before noun head; question word medial; tense and aspect; no passives or voice; CV, CVC, CCV, V, CCVC, CVCCC; tonal; 25 consonant and 5 vowel phonemes.
name: Tamang, Northwestern

Name: Jorto
Classification: Afro-Asiatic, Chadic, West, A, A.3, Angas Proper, 1
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Jorto
Location: Plateau state: Shendam LGA, Dokan Kasuwa.
name: Jorto

Name: Khao
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Northern Mon-Khmer, Khmuic, Khao
Dialects: None known. Related to Bit [bgk] in Laos and China.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Khao
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized ethnic group: Xinh Mun. population 23,278 (2009 census).
Location: Northwest; Son La and Dien Bien provinces, near Ma River, north of Pa Ma.
name: Khao

Name: Pokangá
Alternate Names: Bara Sona, Barasano, Bará, Bará-Tukano, Pakang, Pokangá-Tapuya, Waipínõmakã
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Pokangá
Location: Amazonas state: Upper Tiquie, tributary of Vaupés.
Other Comments: May be the same as Barasana [bsn] or Waimaha [bao] (Northern Barasano, Bará).
name: Pokangá

Name: Kpatili
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Adamawa-Ubangi, Ubangi, Zande, Zande-Nzakara
Dialects: None known. Not intelligible with Gbayi [gyg], who are ethnically Kpatili.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kpatili
Location: Basse-Kotto prefecture: south Mingala subprefecture; Mbomou prefecture: Bakouma subprefecture.
name: Kpatili

Name: Shuwa-Zamani
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Shuwa-Zamani
name: Shuwa-Zamani

Name: Gengle
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Adamawa-Ubangi, Adamawa, Leko-Nimbari, Mumuye-Yandang, Mumuye
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Gengle
Language Use: Also use Hausa [hau]. Used as L2 by Kugama [kow], Teme [tdo].
Location: Adamawa state: Mayo Belwa and Fufore LGAs.
Other Comments: Not the same as Gongla [mzm]. Traditional religion, Christian, Muslim.
name: Gengle

Name: Vono
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Vono
name: Vono

Name: Laba
Dialects: None known. Phonology like Galela [gbi], 70% intelligibility, 75% of Loloda [loa]. Lexical similarity: 75% with Galela [gbi], 78% with Loloda [loa].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Laba
Location: Maluku Utara province: south Loloda district, 4 villages; Halmahera island northwest interior.
name: Laba

Name: Kon Keu
Classification: Austro-Asiatic, Mon-Khmer, Northern Mon-Khmer, Palaungic, Eastern Palaungic, Angkuic
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kon Keu
Location: Yunnan province: Baoshan, Dai Lincang, Simao, and Xishuangbanna autonomous prefectures.
name: Kon Keu

Name: Tumi
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Tumi
name: Tumi

Name: Ontenu
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ontenu
name: Ontenu

Name: Thudam
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, Central Bodish, Unclassified
Dialects: None known. Similar to Walungge [ola] in Nepal and to the varieties spoken in the villages of Kudo and Sar in Tibet (Von Fürer-Haimendorf 1975).
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Thudam
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized indigenous nationality: Thudam.
Language Use: All ages. Some also use Lhomi [lhm], especially older people. Also use Nepali [npi].
Location: Kosi zone: Sankhuwasabha district, Chepuwa VDC, Thudam village.
Other Comments: Culturally akin to the Walungs. Buddhist, Christian.
Typology: SOV; postpositions; content q-word in situ; clause constituents indicated by case-marking; ergativity; no passives or voice; tonal.
name: Thudam

Name: Kaivi
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kaivi
name: Kaivi

Name: Idesa
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Edoid, Northwestern, Southern
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Idesa
Location: Edo state: Owan East LGA, Otuo.
name: Idesa

Name: Lui
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Lui
name: Lui

Name: Dungu
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Dungu
Location: Kaduna state: Saminaka LGA, Dungi town.
name: Dungu

Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Kainji, Eastern, Northern Jos, Kauru
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mala

Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ruma
name: Ruma

Name: Buraka
Also spoken in: {u'View other languages of Democratic Republic of the Congo': {}}
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, North, Adamawa-Ubangi, Ubangi, Sere-Ngbaka-Mba, Ngbaka-Mba, Ngbaka, Western, Gbanzili
Dialects: None known. May not be inherently intelligible with Gbanziri [gbg].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Buraka
Location: Basse-Kotto prefecture: Mobaye subprefecture, along Ubangi river.
name: Buraka

Name: Bainouk-Samik
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Atlantic, Northern, Eastern Senegal-Guinea, Banyun
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Bainouk-Samik
Location: Casamance river south side, mainly Samik area and villages north and east, 20 km east of Ziguinchor.
name: Bainouk-Samik

Name: Adabe
Alternate Names: Ataura, Atauran, Atauro, Atauru, Raklu Un, Raklu-Un
Dialects: Munaseli Pandai, Rahesuk, Raklungu, Resuk. Different from Galolen [gal] dialects on Atauro.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Adabe
Location: Dili district: Atauro island; Timor island north of capital.
name: Adabe

Name: Sentinel
Dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Öñge [oon].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sentinel
Location: Andaman and Nicobar Islands union territory: Sentinel island east of South Andaman island.
Other Comments: A Scheduled Tribe. Reserved toward outsiders. Traditional religion.
name: Sentinel

Name: Ihievbe
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Edoid, North-Central
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ihievbe
Location: Edo state: Owan East LGA, northeast of Afuze, Ihievbe Ogbe, Ebetse, and Iyakhora villages.
name: Ihievbe

Name: Sikiana
Alternate Names: Chikena, Chiquena, Chiquiana, Shikiana, Sikiâna, Sikïiyana, Xikiyana, Xikujana
Dialects: None known. Reportedly similar to Salumá [slj].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Sikiana
Location: Pará state: between Rio Cafuini and headwaters of the Turuna and Itapi, near the Suriname border.
Population: 33 (1986 SIL). Total users in all countries: 48.
name: Sikiana

Name: Tawang Monpa
Alternate Names: Brahmi, Cuona Menba, Dwags, Monkit, Northern Monpa, Takpa, Tawan Monba
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, East Bodish
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Monpa, Tawang
Language Use: Vigorous. Home, village, religion. Positive attitudes. Also use Hindi [hin]. Used as L2 by Sherdukpen [sdp].
Other Comments: Monpa (Moinba), ‘man of the lower country’, refers to several ethnically related peoples, which may not be related linguistically. Buddhist.
name: Monpa, Tawang

Name: Lambichhong
Alternate Names: Lambicchong, Lambichhong, Lambichong, Lambitshong, Phangduwali Mugali
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Himalayan, Kiranti, Eastern
Dialects: Phangdhuwali. Reportedly similar to Chhulung [cur], Belhariya [byw], and Chhintang [ctn].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mugali
Language Status: 7 (Shifting). Language of recognized indigenous nationality: Rai.
Location: Kosi zone: Dhankuta district, Arun river east bank, between Mugakhola and Sinuwakhola; Muga, Pakhribas and Phalate VDCs.
Population: 1,500 (2010 I. Rai), decreasing. Very few monolinguals.
Typology: SOV; postpositions; no gender; verbal affixation marks person and number; split ergativity; tense; no passives or voice; nontonal; 23 consonant and 5 vowel phonemes.
name: Mugali

Name: Maramba
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Maramba
name: Maramba

Name: Lumba-Yakkha
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Himalayan, Kiranti, Eastern
Dialects: They understand Yakkha [ybh], but Yakkha speakers have difficulty in understanding them. No perceived dialect differences within the six villages.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Yakkha, Chhathare
Language Use: Language retained among some youth (Hansson 1991). Home.
Location: Kosi zone: Dhankuta district, 6 villages in Arkhaule Jitpur and Marek Katahare VDCs.
Other Comments: The north part (village of Marek) is most vital and populous area. The Chhathare villages to the south and west no longer speak the language, some loss in the east. Traditional religion, Christian, Hindu.
Typology: SOV; postpositions; noun head final; verbal affixation marks person and number; both tense and aspect, nontonal.
name: Yakkha, Chhathare

Name: Ná-Meo
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ná-Meo
Language Status: 6a (Vigorous). Language of recognized ethnic group: Hmong.
Location: Northwest Lang Son Province, Trang Dinh district, Cao Minh and Khuoi Phu Dao villages, Khanh Long hamlet; Cao Bang Province, Thach An district, Ca Liec village.
Other Comments: Possible immigrants from Guangxi Province in China.
name: Ná-Meo

Name: Giyug
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Giyug
Location: Northern Territory: Anson Bay, Peron islands, southwest of Darwin.
name: Giyug

Name: Phangduwali
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Himalayan, Kiranti, Eastern
Dialects: None known. The language spoken by the Phangduwali people is well-understood by Mugali [lmh] people and vice versa except for a few lexical items and accents.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Phangduwali
Language Status: 7 (Shifting). Language of recognized indigenous nationality: Rai.
Location: Kosi zone: Dhankuta district, Pakhribas VDC, above Mugakhola headwaters.
Other Comments: Van Driem (2001) claims that the Phangduwali are actually Yakkha [ybh], whereas I.P. Rai (forthcoming) suggests these two languages are distinct. Both assert that Phangduwali and Mugali [lmh] are the same language. Traditional religion.
Typology: SOV; postpositions; 23 consonant and 5 vowel phonemes.
name: Phangduwali

Name: Sorsogon Ayta
Classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Greater Central Philippine, Central Philippine
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Ayta, Sorsogon
Location: Bicol region: Sorsogon province, Prieto Diaz municipality.
name: Ayta, Sorsogon

Name: Khalaj
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Khalaj
Other Comments: Different from Turkic Khalaj [klj] in Iran.
name: Khalaj

Name: Mawayana
Dialects: None known. No semantic similarity with and not related to Wapishana [wap], Atorada [aox], or Mapidian [mpw] (2002 R. Hicks).
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Mawayana
Location: Upper Takutu-Upper Essequibo region: southwest, among the Waiwai [waw] language group.
Population: 50 (1986 C. Howard). Total users in all countries: 60.
name: Mawayana

Name: Foia Foia
Dialects: None known. Lexical similarity: 73% with Minanibai [mcv], 52% with Mubami [tsx], 59% with Hoyahoya [hhy], 54% with Hoia Hoia [hhi].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Foia Foia
Language Use: All domains. Some also use Tok Pisin [tpi], at Kamusi. Also use Bamu [bcf]. Used as L2 by Hoia Hoia [hhi].
Location: Western province: Middle Fly district, Bibisa village; Gulf province: Kikori district, Turama river, Moka village.
name: Foia Foia

Name: Nupbikha
Classification: Sino-Tibetan, Tibeto-Burman, Western Tibeto-Burman, Bodish, East Bodish, Bumthang
Dialects: None known. Phonological similarities to Khengkha [xkf].
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Nupbikha
Location: Trongsa district: enclave south of Tongsa Dzong.
Other Comments: View their language as different from Bumthangkha [kjz].
name: Nupbikha

Name: Kosena
Language Development: Literacy rate in L1: 5%–15%. Literacy rate in L2: 5%–15%. NT: 1980.
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Kosena
Location: Eastern Highlands province: Kainantu and Okapa districts.
name: Kosena

Name: Thu Lao
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Thu Lao
Location: Far north, near China border, Lao Cai Province; possibly in Laos.
name: Thu Lao

Name: Badeshi
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Badeshi
Location: Khyber Pakhtunkwa province: Bishigram valley upper reaches, Swat Kohistan; small groups in Pooran Chakesar, Swat, and Tirat valleys; Alai.
Other Comments: Only dominant area languages now used: Torwali [trw], Pashto or Ushojo [ush]. Muslim.
Population: No known L1 speakers. No known speakers for three or more generations. Ethnic population: 2,830 (2000).
name: Badeshi

Name: Áncá
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Unclassified
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Áncá
Location: Taraba state: Sardauna LGA, Antere, Nca village.
Other Comments: May be the same as Manta [myg].
name: Áncá

Name: Fum
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Bantoid, Southern, Wide Grassfields, Narrow Grassfields
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Fum
Location: Taraba state: Sardauna LGA, Antere, on Cameroon border.
Other Comments: May be the same as Mfumte [nfu] in Cameroon.
name: Fum

Name: Odut
Classification: Niger-Congo, Atlantic-Congo, Volta-Congo, Benue-Congo, Cross River, Delta Cross, Upper Cross, Kiong-Korop
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Odut
Population: 20 (1980 R. Blench). May be extinct (Dimmendaal and Voeltz 2007).
name: Odut

Name: Yarsun
Classification: Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Western Oceanic, North New Guinea, Sarmi-Jayapura Bay, Sarmi
Language Resources: OLAC resources in and about Yarsun
Location: Papua province: Sarmi regency, Bonggo sub-district.
Other Comments: Yarsun may not exist or speakers may have moved (2005 SIL). Christian, traditional religion.
name: Yarsun
